wonderful it was to have something to show

2698.54.text:
his friends. And I thought, "My God, there
really is a hell, an African American atheist

2704.59.text:
for 85 years in Amarillo." He was somebody
who revered WEB Du Bois, who, of course, was

2711.45.text:
an atheist, but never got much traction in
the African American community on that issue.

2716.07.text:
BILL MOYERS:
Why are you an atheist?

2718.18.text:
SUSAN JACOBY:
Why? Because it's what makes sense to me.

2723.06.text:
I look at the world around me. I'm an atheist
because of -- which has made a lot of people

2728.36.text:
an atheist, because of the theodicy problem.
The problem of if there is this all good,

2734.05.text:
all powerful, all loving god, you know, how
come kids are shot in Newtown? How come people

2742.28.text:
when I was young died of polio-- a child I
knew? How come?

2748.41.text:
It started me thinking about what every religious
thinker has thought about and had to come

2753.22.text:
to grips with, which is how do you account
for the problem of evil beside your belief

2758.11.text:
in an all-powerful God? Well, the classic
Christian answer, which satisfied Augustine,

2764.47.text:
does not satisfy me or any atheist. Which
is that we have free will. And we are responsible

2770.76.text: for all the evil in the world.

2772.44.text:
No, I think the evolution of the polio virus
and Darwin's theory of how it happened is

2778.41.text:
responsible. That there is no such thing as
intelligent design. If God had been an intelligent

2783.05.text:
designer, what purpose would polio serve?
Well, the answer to that is it's a mystery.

2789.68.text:
We don't know what God's plans are. That's
what my mom told me when I was a kid. My mom

2795.51.text:
stopped going to church when she was 85 years
old.

2800.39.text:
SUSAN JACOBY:
I asked her why. I knew it couldn't be my

2804.48.text:
influence, certainly. She said, "I've been
thinking about the problem of evil. And it

2809.79.text:
makes no sense." She said, "Why should people
suffer?" because, of course, she knew so many

2815.20.text:
people unlike her who had lost their minds
to Alzheimer's. She said, "This makes no sense."

2820.71.text:
She said, "I do not believe that there can
be a God whose plan this could be a part of.

2825.96.text:
I never could have said this when my parents
were alive. If being old is good for anything,

2831.97.text: I can do exactly what I want."

2834.24.text:
BILL MOYERS:
What Robert Ingersoll come to mean to you

2838.68.text: in the great intellectual tradition of America?

2842.87.text:
SUSAN JACOBY:
He -- first of all, he shows how even if you

2847.86.text:
don't get remembered for it in perhaps the
way you should later on, that doesn't deny

2854.65.text:
the role you play anymore. Nobody knew who
Elizabeth Cady Stanton was from about 1900

2861.18.text:
until the new feminism really began to take
hold in the 1980s, because she was written

2866.42.text:
out of the suffragists movement for writing
a book called "The Woman's Bible," which criticized

2871.08.text: all the misogyny in the Bible.

2873.54.text:
The fact that nobody knows about you and maybe
history doesn't give you your just reward

2878.77.text:
and certainly not in every time, because there
are fashions in history, doesn't mean that

2884.05.text: you didn't play an important role.

2886.01.text:
So he carried on a tradition. And just as
those feminists who got written out carried

2891.67.text:
on a tradition which was picked up later on.
And the second reason he's so important is

2899.10.text:
that he is a model of what you have to do
to fight for an unpopular idea. And you can't

2904.17.text:
do it by hiding behind other labels, because
other people are going to criticize you for

2911.57.text:
BILL MOYERS:
You quote Ingersoll saying that the result

2913.12.text:
of all of this public religiosity that was
surrounding him and surrounds us today is

2918.38.text:
that quote, "We reward hypocrisy and elect
men entirely destitute of real principle.

2925.20.text:
And this will never change until the people
become grand enough to do their own thinking."

2931.32.text:
SUSAN JACOBY:
And to admit to their own thinking.

2934.41.text:
BILL MOYERS:
What do you mean?

2936.34.text:
SUSAN JACOBY:
Not just to do their own thinking, but to

2938.96.text:
open up their mouths and tell other people
about their own thinking. When he died, an

2944.81.text:
editor in Kansas said, "There will come a
time when men--" he talked about the political

2951.02.text:
career Ingersoll did. "There will come a time
when men may run for office and speak their

2957.68.text:
honest convictions in matters in religion.
But not yet," he ended his editorial. Can't

2964.65.text: we say that now? "But not yet."

2966.99.text:
BILL MOYERS:
Robert Ingersoll said of Thomas Paine, "His

2970.56.text:
life is what the world calls failure and what
history calls success." Can the same thing

2977.84.text: be said of The Great Agnostic?

2979.33.text:
SUSAN JACOBY:
I hope so. What I would like to see is history

2983.18.text:
calling his life a success more than it has
since the 1920s. That's my aim here. His life

2990.29.text:
was a success. And it should be recognized
as a success and a very important contribution

2996.63.text:
to the cause of reason in this country, one
which is just as relevant today that was when

3002.05.text:
we were fighting about the same issues 125
years ago.

3005.29.text:
BILL MOYERS:
The book is "The Great Agnostic: Robert Ingersoll

3009.33.text:
and American Freethought." Susan Jacoby, thank
you very much for being with us.

3013.72.text:
SUSAN JACOBY:
Thank you. It's a real pleasure.
